headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones. So I noticed there's a decent overlap between the new markets that you've announced for Maxx and pending Google Fiber markets, and I'm just wondering how, sort of, Google moving into fiber is sort of impacting your decision on markets that
componenttext: Two quick ones. So I noticed there's a decent overlap between the new markets that you've announced for Maxx and pending Google Fiber markets, and I'm just wondering how, sort of, Google moving into fiber is sort of impacting your decision on markets that you roll out but also how it impacts the -- sort of the sense of urgency you have around rolling out a voice -- a WiFi-first voice offering given that Google seems to be moving in that direction as well. And then a second question quickly, just on that FCC goes ahead and redefines broadband of -- at 25 megabits per second, how do you think that impacts the calculus of the DOJ on the deal, if at all?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start with your last question. I think that the notion of defining broadband at 25 megabits per second is somewhat arbitrary. I'm not really sure what that is intended to mean, and really, I don't anticipate that, that has any practical implication
componenttext: Let me start with your last question. I think that the notion of defining broadband at 25 megabits per second is somewhat arbitrary. I'm not really sure what that is intended to mean, and really, I don't anticipate that, that has any practical implications for life going forward or for the DOJ's analysis of the deal. In terms of Maxx, as we said, when we first articulated our 3-year plan, our aim is to have 75% of our footprint enabled with Maxx attributes by the end of the 3-year plan period. So -- and my guess is we'll continue to roll it out beyond that, but -- so the only question is prioritization. And obviously, as we think about where to go first, competitive dynamics are a factor. So that includes Google, although it's not explicitly dictated by where Google decides to go. In fact, I think we announced the Carolinas before Google did their announcement this week. So competitive set is certainly relevant, obviously. In terms of urgency around the WiFi-first offering, as I said earlier, I think WiFi-first is an interest as a voice -- WiFi-first voice product is interesting, but we don't have any specific launch plans at this time. So it's something we'll continue to think about.

componenttext: Sure, Frank. I would say there is no real change from what our priorities were, frankly, in '14. I think you'll continue to see us invest in our infrastructure around Maxx. headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: With [indiscernible] of media and everything happening on the M2M side even, it feels like your set-top box data has a lot more value than it did before. Can you talk the ways to monetize that in concert with partners or even by yourself? I know it's a li
componenttext: With [indiscernible] of media and everything happening on the M2M side even, it feels like your set-top box data has a lot more value than it did before. Can you talk the ways to monetize that in concert with partners or even by yourself? I know it's a little conjectural, but it will be interesting to get your thoughts.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is no question that there's a tremendous amount of value in the set-top box data we collect. We're already using that in our ad sales business, had been for some time, compliant with privacy laws, of course. And it also informs the way we make
componenttext: Yes, there is no question that there's a tremendous amount of value in the set-top box data we collect. We're already using that in our ad sales business, had been for some time, compliant with privacy laws, of course. And it also informs the way we make decisions about programming we carry and the way we carry it. So we're already utilizing it for our own business. Whether there are opportunities to monetize that with third parties is something that we've spent a lot of time deliberating on. There are, obviously, countervailing considerations because we want to make sure that it's not used in ways that are either inconsistent with the law or inconsistent with our business priorities. So it -- well, there's no question there's value in the asset, but we're not in a position right now to announce any particular monetization plans away from using it to enhance our own business.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to the Time Warner Cable Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.
Now I'll turn the call over to Mr. Tom Robey, Senior Vice President of Time Warner Cable, Investor Relations. Thank you, you may begin.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Candy, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Time Warner Cable's 2014 Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we issued a press release detailing our 2014 fourth quarter and full year results.Before we begin, there
componenttext:
Thanks, Candy, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Time Warner Cable's 2014 Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we issued a press release detailing our 2014 fourth quarter and full year results.
Before we begin, there are several items I need to cover. First, we refer to certain non-GAAP measures. Definitions and schedules setting out reconciliations of these historical non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are included in our earnings release and trending schedules. Second, today's conference call includes certain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which are based on management's current expectations and beliefs and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results may vary materially from those expressed or implied by the statements herein due to various factors which are discussed in detail in our SEC filings. Time Warner Cable is under no obligation to, and in fact expressly disclaims any such obligation, to update or alter its forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. Third, the quarterly growth rates disclosed in this conference call are on a year-over-year basis, unless otherwise noted as being sequential. Fourth, today's press release, trending schedules, presentation slides and related reconciliation schedules are available on our website at twc.com/investors.
And finally, following prepared comments by Rob Marcus and Artie Minson, Rob, Artie and our Chief Operating Officer, Dinni Jain, will be available to answer your questions.
With that covered, I'll thank you, and turn the call over to Rob. Rob?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Q4 marked a strong finish to a really positive year for Time Warner Cable. Fourth quarter revenue growth of 3.8% and adjusted OIBDA growth of 5.6% were the best of the year, and our focus on residential subscriber
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Q4 marked a strong finish to a really positive year for Time Warner Cable. Fourth quarter revenue growth of 3.8% and adjusted OIBDA growth of 5.6% were the best of the year, and our focus on residential subscriber growth was evident in our standout sub numbers across all categories. In particular, residential customer relationship net adds of 54,000 were the best in any fourth quarter since we went public, and residential triple play net adds of 273,000 were the most in any fourth quarter ever.
It was just about a year ago that we laid out our 3-year operating and strategic plan for Time Warner Cable. As a core element of that plan, we set out to revitalize our residential business by refocusing on growing our customer base, investing in reliability and customer service and enhancing our product set. Also key to the plan, we committed to drive continued growth in business services by expanding our network, augmenting our sales force and increasing productivity. Even with our February agreement to merge with Comcast and all of the associated distractions, our team has stayed 100% committed to the plan, the results show, and I couldn't be prouder of what we've been able to accomplish this past year. Our efforts put us ahead of plan in almost every operational category. For the full year 2014, we added 150,000 residential customer relationships and 373,000 triple plays, a radical turnaround from the past several years.
Not only are we ahead of plan from a subscriber perspective, but we're also ahead of schedule on many of our customer-experience-focused initiatives. We completed our TWC Maxx speed increases in New York City, Los Angeles and Austin, and our all digital conversion is done in New York City and L.A. and in process in Austin. These investments, along with investments we've made in new set-top boxes and modems, WiFi Hotspots and better reliability and customer service, are already having an impact on customer satisfaction. And critically, customers in TWC Maxx markets with our new modems have churn rates that are materially lower than customers in non-Maxx markets. It's still early days, but those are exactly the proof points we banked on. Needless to say, we're very enthusiastic about launching Maxx in 7 additional markets this year.
We're also ahead of schedule in key customer service metrics. In Q4, our techs arrived within our industry-leading 1-hour appointment windows an astounding 97% of the time, and rework is down to historically low levels, meaning we are doing it better -- doing better at resolving customers' issues the first time. We're ahead of plan in investing in our plant and CPE reliability, too. Our planned health metrics look great, but more important, from our customers' perspective, is that trouble calls per customer relationship were 18% lower in December than a year earlier.
And we continue to deliver even better products. We'll complete the expansion of VOD capacity to 75,000 hours next quarter. That's more than a fivefold increase in just a couple of years. Our TWC TV App keeps getting better, with more linear networks and VOD choices available on more devices both inside and outside the home. In Q4, we saw usage of TWC TV continue to grow. In December, almost 1 million video subscribers used the app. We added unlimited China and Hong Kong calling to our phone service, which already included unlimited calling throughout North America. And we've expanded public WiFi dramatically, so our customers can enjoy the benefits of broadband in more places. December WiFi sessions topped 28 million, up more than 30% over the end of Q3.
As I mentioned, business services growth is critical to our operating plan. Business services revenue grew nearly 23% for both the fourth quarter and the full year, and business services OIBDA margin continues to expand. Our business services strategy is working, and we're right on track to reach $5 billion in annual revenue by 2018. Our ad sales team also stepped up in 2014, making the most of the opportunity created by the midterm elections. We generated $113 million of political advertising revenue, essentially matching our record of 2012 performance and contributing to full year ad revenue growth of more than 10%.
So we accomplished an awful lot in 2014. While we were slightly shy of our 2014 financial objectives, I'd argue that we overdelivered operationally. As a result of our really outstanding sub performance, we entered 2015 with a healthier, bigger customer base than we had planned and terrific subscriber momentum. And as a result of our investment in our plant, our equipment, our products, and our care and tech ops capabilities, we are very well positioned for the future.
Of course, we continue to work with Comcast and Charter to obtain the regulatory approvals necessary to close our merger as well as to plan for the integration of our companies. The deal will be great for our customers and our shareholders, and we look forward to closing soon. In the meantime, we are committed to executing on our plan and building on 2014's operating momentum.
With that as an overview, let me ask Artie to briefly cover the key takeaways from our fourth quarter results. Artie?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob, and good morning, everyone. Before I get going, I'd like to hit a couple of housekeeping items that are probably pretty obvious, but worth mentioning anyway. As Rob mentioned, we continue to expect the closing of our merger with Comcast will
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob, and good morning, everyone. Before I get going, I'd like to hit a couple of housekeeping items that are probably pretty obvious, but worth mentioning anyway. As Rob mentioned, we continue to expect the closing of our merger with Comcast will occur early this year. As a result, we're not going to be providing full year guidance today nor are we announcing an increase to our regular dividend. Those are both things we typically do on our Q4 call, but not appropriate today given where we stand in the deal process.
I'm going to start today by rewinding the clock to our fourth quarter 2013 earnings call. As you will recall, we spent a good bit of time walking through our 3-year operating and financial plan to revitalize TWC. As Rob indicated in his opening remarks, we are running ahead of that plan operationally. Our residential subscriber metrics are better than expected. Our customer care and tech ops performance is the best in recent memory. Our TWC Maxx rollout is accelerating, and business services continues to be a strong driver of growth. On the financial side, I'm also pleased with our performance and with the go-forward for financial trajectory of the business, albeit off a modestly lower 2014 base.
With that, let me turn to the Q4 highlights, starting with customer relationships, where we performed very well. On the residential side, we gained 54,000 customer relationships in Q4. In business services, we added 13,000 CRs. So on a combined basis, we had the best results for a Q4 at least since the time of the Adelphia transaction in 2006. The Q4 residential CR performance was driven by a 7% increase in connects, coupled with a 7% improvement in disconnects. You might recall that back in 2013, we moved to dedicated retention centers. This approach continues to pay dividends as we saw continued improvements in churn reduction. And on the connect front, we saw improvements across all major sales channels, particularly inbound sales, online and direct sales.
Our fourth quarter subscriber results topped off a strong year. Full year residential CR net adds of 150,000 were 440,000 better than last year and 0.25 million better than in 2012. You will recall that a major driver of our operating financial plan was to add 1 million residential CRs between 2014 and 2016 so that we could get back to more balanced residential revenue growth from volume and rate. Our 2014 residential CR performance exceeded our expectations, and we entered 2015 with strong momentum.
PSU performance in Q4 also was outstanding. Residential PSU net adds of 425,000 were 600,000 better than last year's Q4 and 445,000 better than in 2012. All geographic markets performed better than in the fourth quarter of 2012 and 2013. The PSU growth was driven by CR increases as well as particularly strong triple play net adds, with triple play connects more than doubling over the last year. At year-end, residential triples increased to 30% of the base. Triples now represent 46% of monthly recurring revenue, which is up approximately 300 basis points from a year ago.
On an individual product basis, residential video net declines of 38,000 were the best Q4 since 2006, 179,000 better than last year and 91,000 better than 2012. We saw an improvement in video performance as we went through the quarter, and in December, we had positive video net adds. Broadband volume also was very strong. Residential net adds of 168,000 were the best for a fourth quarter in 7 years and were, in fact, higher than the net adds in all of 2013. Phone net adds of 295,000 were the strongest in a fourth quarter ever. As we have completed our migration of our phone product to our internal platform, we are able to much more cost effectively offer phone as a value-added product to our customers. This has helped us drive triple play sell-in, and we also continue to benefit from product rollouts in phone, such as free calling to Mexico, Hong Kong and China.
With that, let's move on to our Q4 financial results. Total revenue of $5.8 billion was up 3.8% year-over-year. Residential services revenue grew $21 million or 0.5% year-over-year, driven by a 7.4% increase in broadband revenue. Consistent with our residential 3-year plan, more of the revenue growth came from volume than from rate.
In business services, revenue increased $139 million or 22.6% year-over-year in Q4. The core business here continues to be very, very healthy. In fact, if you exclude the slow-growing video product, revenue growth for the remaining products in the segment, data, voice and transport, was almost 26%. Operating leverage continues to be a big part of the story here. Sales rep productivity continued to improve in Q4, and we continued to manage costs aggressively. As a result, business services adjusted OIBDA margin increased by approximately 180 basis points to about 62%.
Other operations revenue grew 16.1% in Q4. Media sales revenue was really strong, increasing more than 19% year-over-year, primarily due to growth in political advertising revenue, which was $61 million in the quarter versus $7 million in last year's Q4. Excluding political, ad revenue was flat year-over-year. And while full year 2014 advertising revenue of $1.1 billion was an all-time record, it did include $113 million of political revenue, making 2015 a difficult comparison. Fourth quarter other revenue increased primarily due to affiliate fees from our residential services segment as well as other distributors for carriage of the Lakers RSNs.
We grew total company adjusted OIBDA 5.6% in Q4. This reflects the strongest organic growth we've seen in recent years. While the adjusted OIBDA growth was strong, it was a little bit light from what we had been projecting for adjusted OIBDA at the end of Q3. Nothing really noteworthy here other than there were, frankly, a few good guys we had been forecasting on the expense side that didn't materialize and there were a few expense bad guys around insurance accruals and legal settlements that we had not forecasted that negatively impacted us.
Programming costs for residential sub, including an intercompany charge for market-rate RSN deals, increased 12.5% to a little over $39. Keep in mind that the launches of new networks, such as the SEC Network last summer, somewhat skewed the year-over-year programming cost comparison. These new launches will, obviously, impact 2015 programming cost growth as well.
Tech ops and customer care together increased $42 million or 7.5%. The investments we're making in these areas have been instrumental in building a better customer experience. Higher sales expense in the quarter was more than offset by lower marketing costs, particularly in the areas of broadcast and production costs, as we have strategically reallocated our marketing investment to sales channels, such as inbound sales and direct sales reps.
Moving down the income statement. Fourth quarter adjusted diluted EPS was very strong at $2.03, up 11.5%. And for the year, adjusted diluted EPS grew 14.4% to $7.56. I would remind you that with the suspension of our share repurchase program when we announced the Comcast transaction, share count reduction now has a smaller impact on EPS growth. In fact, not much at all in Q4.
Free cash flow was $891 million in the fourth quarter. On a full year basis, free cash flow of $2.3 billion was down 9.9% from 2013, primarily due to higher capital expenditures.
CapEx of $4.1 billion in 2014 increased by almost $900 million from 2013, reflecting improvements to the plant, our aggressive investment in CPE as we continue to deploy new set-tops, DTAs and modems in Maxx markets, and our accelerated replacement of older, less reliable set-tops across the footprint.
We also continue to invest in the future growth of business services. We connected nearly 70,000 buildings to our network in 2014, bringing the total number of connected buildings to 930,000.
So net-net, I am very pleased with our continued momentum, and until we close, we will run as hard as we can to the finish line and make good on our promise to deliver the company to Comcast in very good shape.
With that, let me turn it back over to Tom for the Q&A portion of the call.

componenttext: You mentioned there was a decline in churn. I was wondering if you could say how much. Also, could you give us any guidance for CapEx for 2015? And then finally, with the increase in buildings, what is the current addressable SME market?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm not going to able to help. Despite asking 3 questions, I'm not sure how much I'm going to be able to help you on any of those. We're not going to break out CapEx. We're really staying away from any forward-looking guidance for 2015. On the churn
componenttext: Sure. I'm not going to able to help. Despite asking 3 questions, I'm not sure how much I'm going to be able to help you on any of those. We're not going to break out CapEx. We're really staying away from any forward-looking guidance for 2015. On the churn, that's really nothing we've ever disclosed. What I'll just sort of stick with is the overall comment that we had a very good improvement in connects and disconnects, but you should take away that churn reduction has, obviously, been a key focus of ours. And your last question on the buildings we've added, in our footprint, the addressable market size is -- it's a little under $25 billion.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is John Hodulik with UBS.
componenttext: Next question is John Hodulik with UBS.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Guys, on their call, AT&T announced a new strategy as it relates to U-verse. They're pulling back on -- focus on sub growth, just focusing on higher end subs, and as a result, in the fourth quarter, they added far fewer subs than they did last year. I thi
componenttext: Guys, on their call, AT&T announced a new strategy as it relates to U-verse. They're pulling back on -- focus on sub growth, just focusing on higher end subs, and as a result, in the fourth quarter, they added far fewer subs than they did last year. I think that took place through the quarter. Do you guys -- I guess I have 2 questions. One, do you guys think that, that had any impact on -- are you seeing a change in the competitive environment as a result of that? Did it affect the strength that you saw, especially in December, where I think you said you went positive? And then if you could, if you know, give us a sense on where your overlap with the U-verse footprint stands at this point given their recent build-out?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, I can take both of those. It's Rob. Overlap with U-verse is at about 26% of our footprint today. For good measure, I'll throw in that we're about 14% overlapped by FiOS. As far as your overall question as to what the impact of AT&T's strategy w
componenttext: Yes, John, I can take both of those. It's Rob. Overlap with U-verse is at about 26% of our footprint today. For good measure, I'll throw in that we're about 14% overlapped by FiOS. As far as your overall question as to what the impact of AT&T's strategy was on our performance, hard to attribute our outperformance to any one factor. We did do well in U-verse markets. We did well in FiOS markets for that matter, too. We grew connects in both FiOS and U-verse markets, and in fact, our disconnect reduction in FiOS and U-verse markets was better than in non-FiOS and U-verse markets. So beyond that, I'm not sure I can be more specific in addressing your particular question.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Phil Cusick with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next question is Phil Cusick with JPMorgan.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So nice job on subs. I did notice, though, that ARPU trended a little lower than we expected. Is this just because of bringing on a lot of new subs on promotion? Is it a higher hit from retention? Or is it about ramping, sort of, people up less quickly as
componenttext: So nice job on subs. I did notice, though, that ARPU trended a little lower than we expected. Is this just because of bringing on a lot of new subs on promotion? Is it a higher hit from retention? Or is it about ramping, sort of, people up less quickly as they come off contract? And recognizing that you aren't giving guidance, should we look for ARPU to grow more slowly this year given the focus on subscribers?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phil, it's Artie. I'll -- I can take that one. A couple of things I would just point out in ARPU. One is as we move to a new offer in Q4 that had a free installation, if you combine sort of the free installation impact and -- as well as lower pay-per-view
componenttext: Phil, it's Artie. I'll -- I can take that one. A couple of things I would just point out in ARPU. One is as we move to a new offer in Q4 that had a free installation, if you combine sort of the free installation impact and -- as well as lower pay-per-view events, what we would sort of call nonrecurring ARPU, that had -- those had an impact. And actually, what we sort of refer to as monthly recurring ARPU, that was actually up slightly. The other item I would just sort of point out when you think about ARPU, you'll recall when -- that this year, in '14, was the first year we moved to what we call unified rate strategy, meaning that no matter what sort of bundle you are in, whether you're double play, triple play, you receive one rate increase a year. That's different and causes comparisons to '13, when we were sort of doing more product rate increases, meaning if you were a double or a triple, you could actually get multiple rate increases throughout the year. So that, obviously, has a skewing impact on ARPU growth. What I would point out to you is, we're basically getting right into, in '15, the rollout of our '15 rate increases. So you should expect a step-up in ARPU from rates and fees that we will be implementing. You'll get a partial quarter impact of that in Q1 and a full quarter impact in Q2.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Ben Swinburne with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question is Ben Swinburne with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess another attempt at guidance even though we're not supposed to ask about it, but Rob, you said, I think in December, that you thought you guys would add video subs in '15. I just wanted to see -- given the fourth quarter result, I'm guessing you st
componenttext: I guess another attempt at guidance even though we're not supposed to ask about it, but Rob, you said, I think in December, that you thought you guys would add video subs in '15. I just wanted to see -- given the fourth quarter result, I'm guessing you still feel confident, but I wanted to check. And then Artie, any -- could you size those onetime expenses in Q4 just so we can understand the variance versus your expectations, the one-timers you called out?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, so Ben, our plan continues to be to grow video subs in 2015.
componenttext: Sure. Yes, so Ben, our plan continues to be to grow video subs in 2015.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: And Ben, on the expense front, I would say the aggregate of good guys we thought we were going to get on the expense side and some bad guys that we had not forecasted, they're in about the $25 million range.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Laura Martin with Needham & Company.
componenttext: Next question is Laura Martin with Needham & Company.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rob, I want to borrow some of your IQ on 2 big strategic questions. First is, I'm very interested in your commentary around Sling TV and whether you think you guys would offer a similar bundle from those same content guys. And then for the purposes of my
componenttext: Rob, I want to borrow some of your IQ on 2 big strategic questions. First is, I'm very interested in your commentary around Sling TV and whether you think you guys would offer a similar bundle from those same content guys. And then for the purposes of my second question assumptions, assume that Comcast deal doesn't close in '15 or '16, talk about net neutrality and how you're thinking about the investment as we get the net neutrality version that Chairman Wheeler has been talking about, and ultimately -- and then litigation immediately after and that uncertainty and how it would affect your investment in the last mile.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: ;Sure. First, Laura, on Sling TV, we've been advocates of flexible video packages for quite some time. I think Sling TV is a variation on that theme with only 12 -- I believe, 12 networks, select networks from, I think, 3 providers or 4 providers for a
componenttext:
;
Sure. First, Laura, on Sling TV, we've been advocates of flexible video packages for quite some time. I think Sling TV is a variation on that theme with only 12 -- I believe, 12 networks, select networks from, I think, 3 providers or 4 providers for a relatively low price. I think it's intriguing in the sense that it reflects a willingness of programmers to deviate from the big bundle packages that we've generally offered. In terms of the attractiveness of Sling TV itself, I'm a little bit skeptical, in that I think we've got a more compelling light, if you will, bundle that happens to be called our Starter video product, Basic cable, for about the same price, but with many more highly rated networks. So I think we'll watch. And we're certainly interested in more flexible packages, but I'm not sure that that's the right one. In terms of net neutrality, I'd rather answer your question not in terms of what if the Comcast deal doesn't close because we remain confident that it will, but I'll talk generally about net neutrality. I think, at this point, I don't have any greater knowledge of exactly what's going to come out of the FCC than you probably do. If we read Chairman Wheeler's recent statements, it appears that they're going down a Title II with forbearance path, but the exact contours of that, I think, remains to be seen. And the impact that anything they come up with will have on our future investment or willingness to invest, I think, will, in part, depend on the details. I think it's -- it almost goes without saying that to the extent what they proffer creates uncertainty around the regulatory regime in which we will be operating, that is likely to chill our enthusiasm for investment. But beyond that general statement, it's hard to say more.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Mike McCormack with Jefferies.
componenttext: Next question is Mike McCormack with Jefferies.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know you mentioned that you don't want to talk about 2015 guidance at all, but I guess, just thinking about capital intensity, guys, if you look at the current year versus the prior year, the nice turnaround in subs, just, I guess, thinking long-term ca
componenttext: I know you mentioned that you don't want to talk about 2015 guidance at all, but I guess, just thinking about capital intensity, guys, if you look at the current year versus the prior year, the nice turnaround in subs, just, I guess, thinking long-term capital intensity, what would be the view around that? And then, if you don't mind, on voice additions, obviously, very strong, just trying to get a sense for whether if pricing was a tool there, whether that was used for triple play uptake, just any thoughts on why voice was so strong.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me fend off yet another attempt at getting guidance. On CapEx, the only thing we're going to say is that we've, obviously, invested aggressively in our plant reliability and our customer premises equipment in 2014, and our plan is to continue to do th
componenttext: Let me fend off yet another attempt at getting guidance. On CapEx, the only thing we're going to say is that we've, obviously, invested aggressively in our plant reliability and our customer premises equipment in 2014, and our plan is to continue to do that in '15 as we roll out Maxx to more markets and continue to improve the customer experience. But we're not going to say anything more about specifics on capital. I don't know. Dinni, do you want to tackle the phone question?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think, Mike, that, as Artie has been saying, we've done a lot of work in the last couple of years in terms of reducing our cost base in phone and -- so we feel really good about that. We are adding a lot more triple play, as you surmised, a
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think, Mike, that, as Artie has been saying, we've done a lot of work in the last couple of years in terms of reducing our cost base in phone and -- so we feel really good about that. We are adding a lot more triple play, as you surmised, and phone is being brought along in those triple plays at rates that we have not ever seen before. So I think...

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the only other thing I would add is, the double to triple migration, we're also seeing there a nice step-up in revenue from phone. And we can probably be, frankly, a little bit more aggressive than we've been in the past given how we've reduced the co
componenttext: And the only other thing I would add is, the double to triple migration, we're also seeing there a nice step-up in revenue from phone. And we can probably be, frankly, a little bit more aggressive than we've been in the past given how we've reduced the cost structure, but we're still getting a nice step-up there as well.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure we mentioned it, but we've been promoting a $10 bolt-on phone offer for existing customers, and we've had some pretty good success with that.
componenttext: I'm not sure we mentioned it, but we've been promoting a $10 bolt-on phone offer for existing customers, and we've had some pretty good success with that.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess that's what I was trying to get at, is phone that attractive as sort of a -- not a toss-in, but a relatively cheaper throw-on for the bundle that makes you differentiated versus the competitors out there.
componenttext: I guess that's what I was trying to get at, is phone that attractive as sort of a -- not a toss-in, but a relatively cheaper throw-on for the bundle that makes you differentiated versus the competitors out there.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that, as we've mentioned, too, this year we added free calls to Mexico and then, more recently, free calls to China and Hong Kong. And those are being targeted against demographic groups that find really high value in that.
componenttext: Yes. I think that, as we've mentioned, too, this year we added free calls to Mexico and then, more recently, free calls to China and Hong Kong. And those are being targeted against demographic groups that find really high value in that.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: What's kind of interesting is that a reasonable share of the phone net adds that we had, meaning the bolt-on $10 phone net adds, were previous voice cord cutters, in other words wireless onlys. So I think we've struck an offer that's actually interesting
componenttext: What's kind of interesting is that a reasonable share of the phone net adds that we had, meaning the bolt-on $10 phone net adds, were previous voice cord cutters, in other words wireless onlys. So I think we've struck an offer that's actually interesting enough to pick up some of those customers that we  had previously lost when the price was a little higher.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Marci Ryvicker with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Next question is Marci Ryvicker with Wells Fargo.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Stephan Bisson for Marci. You guys have a very expensive and robust WiFi network, and recently, other operators have talked about monetizing it in a different way. Do you have any plans for a similar monetization or -- in that product or
componenttext: This is actually Stephan Bisson for Marci. You guys have a very expensive and robust WiFi network, and recently, other operators have talked about monetizing it in a different way. Do you have any plans for a similar monetization or -- in that product or something different, whether it be voice-based or charging for it?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stephan, we're huge proponents of WiFi. We've been building out our WiFi network for some time. And with the benefit of our consortium with other cable operators, we have what I think is the largest national WiFi network available to our customers of
componenttext: Yes, Stephan, we're huge proponents of WiFi. We've been building out our WiFi network for some time. And with the benefit of our consortium with other cable operators, we have what I think is the largest national WiFi network available to our customers of any provider. And the -- to date, we've used that as a value add to our high-speed data product. But I think that's really just the beginning, and the idea of utilizing WiFi as a component of a voice offering is pretty intriguing. So I assume what you're referring to is the announcement that Cablevision made earlier this week, and it's pretty intriguing to us. We actually implemented a somewhat similar strategy when we had our MVNO arrangement with Clearwire, in that we offered a small bundle of data. It wasn't a voice product, but it was a WiFi-first data offering with an MVNO cellular backup. And in theory, as the technology for voice over WiFi continues to improve, it's theoretically kind of interesting to think about a variation on what Cablevision is doing. So we're going to watch that, see what the uptake is. I'm not sure that they've struck exactly the right chord in terms of the match between price in the absence of a cellular backup, but I think it's pretty cool.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Craig Moffett with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: Our next question is Craig Moffett with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm going to see if I can slip in 2 questions, if I could. First, maybe in light of the expected Title II offering -- or Title II order coming from the FCC, can you talk about your latest thinking on usage-based pricing and whether you think a usage rate
componenttext: I'm going to see if I can slip in 2 questions, if I could. First, maybe in light of the expected Title II offering -- or Title II order coming from the FCC, can you talk about your latest thinking on usage-based pricing and whether you think a usage rate pricing is actually more likely under Title II and what implications the regulatory environment might have for that? And then second, let's change the topic from if the deal doesn't happen to if it does. Assuming it does, can you talk about what you've learned about the migration of programming rate cards for the various subscribers that are going be swapped one way and the other? I mean, how much of the subscriber base can be swapped on to lower rate cards and how quickly?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the -- in terms of the implications of Title II for usage-based pricing, I would really say that I don't think it has much impact at all. As you guys know, we offer usage-based tiers, and I think the ultimate success of usage-based pricing will be depe
componenttext: So the -- in terms of the implications of Title II for usage-based pricing, I would really say that I don't think it has much impact at all. As you guys know, we offer usage-based tiers, and I think the ultimate success of usage-based pricing will be dependent on customer uptake and the interest in availing -- customers' interest in availing themselves of a usage-based tier versus an unlimited tier. The reason I don't think Title II has much of an impact is that, today, the types of rules that are being talked about to ensure an open Internet are wholly consistent with our behaviors and wholly consistent with the rest of the ISP industry's behaviors. So I don't think anything is going to change on that front, and usage-based pricing doesn't seem to be a target of any regulations at this point. And so I think that will continue to be something that may evolve with the market. In terms of programming costs and post-deal application of Comcast deals versus our deals, I don't think we have anything to add to what's already been discussed. And it's probably a conversation that's better had with Comcast to the extent you want to have it.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is James Ratcliffe with Buckingham Research Group.
componenttext: Next question is James Ratcliffe with Buckingham Research Group.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two, if I could as well. First of all, on the business services front, can you give any color on the impact that the expanded footprint actually had on the revenue growth? Because I noticed you picked up sequentially in the growth rate in 4Q. How much of
componenttext: Two, if I could as well. First of all, on the business services front, can you give any color on the impact that the expanded footprint actually had on the revenue growth? Because I noticed you picked up sequentially in the growth rate in 4Q. How much of this is expanding the penetration of the existing base? And how much of it is growing into the 8% of the base or so that you added? And if -- just an idea of how much of the 8% you think you can continue to penetrate over time? And secondly, the marketing strategy on triple play, I think Artie mentioned -- or, excuse me, Rob, you mentioned the $10 add-in. Is this an overall shift toward more marketing triple play? Or how much of this is just 4Q different sorts of addressable customers versus the college students in 3Q?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Let me start on the business services, and then Dinni will take the triple play, and Artie maybe fill in on the business services question as well. Our plan in 2014 was to expand our addressable or serviceable business services revenue opportun
componenttext: All right. Let me start on the business services, and then Dinni will take the triple play, and Artie maybe fill in on the business services question as well. Our plan in 2014 was to expand our addressable or serviceable business services revenue opportunity by about $1.2 billion. And I think the buildings we connected ended up yielding just about that, but that's sort of -- the actual revenue implications of those kinds of builds are lagging. So what you saw in 2014 in terms of revenue growth was really a product of prior investment as well as continued growth in our sales force and productivity within the sales force. So I think 2014's investment will ultimately yield fruit in '15, '16 and then so on. I don't know if you want to add to that, Artie.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, nothing to add.
componenttext: No, nothing to add.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of the triple plays, I think everything that we're doing right now, we're filtering through a lens of how do we build trust with our customers. And through most of 2014, we had a $79 triple play offer that was out there. But Q4, what we really di
componenttext: In terms of the triple plays, I think everything that we're doing right now, we're filtering through a lens of how do we build trust with our customers. And through most of 2014, we had a $79 triple play offer that was out there. But Q4, what we really did was focus on making sure that the package delivered all the elements that were necessary to enjoy the package without this perception of hidden fees. So one of the things we did is we moved the price from $79.99 to $89, and we added the set-top box to it. And then we also, as Artie mentioned, made a free install for triple plays. I think there were a couple other little moves, but that was the core of the change that we made for Q4. And we really feel good about not just the results of it, but also about the entering position with the relationship with the customer and building trust during the course of the whole year. A couple of other things that we have said about the triple play is that we didn't want to have premiums attached to it that expired after 3 months or 6 months. We wanted to keep everything in that 12-month range, and we also didn't want to have rate increases that would affect those customers within the first 12 months. So that's our overall triple play strategy, and it reflects some minor incremental changes, but nothing tremendous.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Vijay Jayant with ISI.
componenttext: Next question is Vijay Jayant with ISI.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's David Joyce for Vijay. On the great subscriber numbers here in the quarter, how confident are you that you won't have the experience you -- that you did a year ago or so when customers are moved up to full-freight pricing? What might be different thi
componenttext: It's David Joyce for Vijay. On the great subscriber numbers here in the quarter, how confident are you that you won't have the experience you -- that you did a year ago or so when customers are moved up to full-freight pricing? What might be different this time in terms of managing the churn? And secondly, what did any kind of skinny packages contribute in the quarter?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think with regards to your first question, I think I partially answered it in my previous answer, which is to say that in the past, when some triple play offers were put out there with too many promotional discounts, when those discounts expired, the
componenttext: So I think with regards to your first question, I think I partially answered it in my previous answer, which is to say that in the past, when some triple play offers were put out there with too many promotional discounts, when those discounts expired, the perception of the price increase was much bigger. Since we didn't add many of those elements to our current triple play package, we're not going to have that effect at the end of the 12-month period. So I think we feel really good about how this package will perform when the promotional period ends at the end of the 12 months.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And David, what I would just say is, in your question on skinny packages, what I would point you to, back to my proactive remarks, where triple play connects have basically doubled over the last year. And I think one of the things of the new offer is it's
componenttext: And David, what I would just say is, in your question on skinny packages, what I would point you to, back to my proactive remarks, where triple play connects have basically doubled over the last year. And I think one of the things of the new offer is it's very clear to our customers, and it's very clear, frankly, to our sales agents of what it is we're selling. So we have gotten the most pickup in selling the triple play offer, which was what we intended when we launched it.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Tom Eagan with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Our next question is Tom Eagan with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: With the upcoming launch of HBO over-the-top, could you give us any updated thoughts you have on the impact on your customers?
componenttext: With the upcoming launch of HBO over-the-top, could you give us any updated thoughts you have on the impact on your customers?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it remains to be seen, but we're going to continue to sell premium services. And I don't anticipate it having a meaningful impact.
componenttext: I think it remains to be seen, but we're going to continue to sell premium services. And I don't anticipate it having a meaningful impact.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Jonathan Chaplin with New Street Research.
componenttext: Next question is Jonathan Chaplin with New Street Research.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones. So I noticed there's a decent overlap between the new markets that you've announced for Maxx and pending Google Fiber markets, and I'm just wondering how, sort of, Google moving into fiber is sort of impacting your decision on markets that
componenttext: Two quick ones. So I noticed there's a decent overlap between the new markets that you've announced for Maxx and pending Google Fiber markets, and I'm just wondering how, sort of, Google moving into fiber is sort of impacting your decision on markets that you roll out, but also how it impacts the -- sort of the sense of urgency you have around rolling out a voice -- a WiFi-first voice offering, given that Google seems to be moving in that direction as well. And then a second question quickly, just on if the FCC goes ahead and redefines broadband of -- at 25 megabits per second, how do you think that impacts the calculus of the DOJ on the deal, if at all?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start with your last question. I think that the notion of defining broadband at 25 megabits per second is somewhat arbitrary. I'm not really sure what that is intended to mean, and really, I don't anticipate that, that has any practical implication
componenttext: Let me start with your last question. I think that the notion of defining broadband at 25 megabits per second is somewhat arbitrary. I'm not really sure what that is intended to mean, and really, I don't anticipate that, that has any practical implications for life going forward or for the DOJ's analysis of the deal. In terms of Maxx, as we said, when we first articulated our 3-year plan, our aim is to have 75% of our footprint enabled with Maxx attributes by the end of the 3-year plan period. So -- and my guess is we'll continue to roll it out beyond that, but -- so the only question is prioritization. And obviously, as we think about where to go first, competitive dynamics are a factor. So that includes Google, although it's not explicitly dictated by where Google decides to go. In fact, I think we announced the Carolinas before Google did their announcement this week. So competitive set is certainly relevant, obviously. In terms of urgency around the WiFi-first offering, as I said earlier, I think WiFi-first is an interest as a voice -- WiFi-first voice product is interesting, but we don't have any specific launch plans at this time. So it's something we'll continue to think about.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Frank Louthan with Raymond James.
componenttext: Next question is Frank Louthan with Raymond James.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Within the CapEx budget for next year, can you give us an idea of sort of the priorities? How much of it is sort of outside plant or expansion of some of the Maxx versus maybe success-based CapEx and capitalizing where your investment has been? Just give
componenttext: Within the CapEx budget for next year, can you give us an idea of sort of the priorities? How much of it is sort of outside plant or expansion of some of the Maxx versus maybe success-based CapEx and capitalizing where your investment has been? Just give us an idea of what -- where the priorities are for the mix.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Frank. I would say there is no real change from what our priorities were, frankly, in '14. I think you'll continue to see us invest in our infrastructure around Maxx. You'll continue to see us deploy new equipment. You'll continue to see us continue
componenttext: Sure, Frank. I would say there is no real change from what our priorities were, frankly, in '14. I think you'll continue to see us invest in our infrastructure around Maxx. You'll continue to see us deploy new equipment. You'll continue to see us continue to add buildings to our footprint for business services. So really, the priorities remain the same.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: With the fracturing of media and everything happening on the M2M side even, it feels like your set-top box data has a lot more value than it did before. Can you talk about the ways to monetize that in concert with partners or even by yourself? I know it's
componenttext: With the fracturing of media and everything happening on the M2M side even, it feels like your set-top box data has a lot more value than it did before. Can you talk about the ways to monetize that in concert with partners or even by yourself? I know it's a little conjectural, but would be interested to get your thoughts.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is no question that there's a tremendous amount of value in the set-top box data we collect. We're already using that in our ad sales business, have been for some time, compliant with privacy laws, of course. And it also informs the way we make
componenttext: Yes, there is no question that there's a tremendous amount of value in the set-top box data we collect. We're already using that in our ad sales business, have been for some time, compliant with privacy laws, of course. And it also informs the way we make decisions about programming we carry and the way we carry it. So we're already utilizing it for our own business. Whether there are opportunities to monetize that with third parties is something that we've spent a lot of time deliberating on. There are, obviously, countervailing considerations because we want to make sure that it's not used in ways that are either inconsistent with the law or inconsistent with our business priorities. So it -- well, there's no question there's value in the asset, but we're not in a position right now to announce any particular monetization plans away from using it to enhance our own business.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, Rob, with regard to the -- your outlook for the integration of Comcast, can you give a sense of what's your time frame after the deal closes, what you're currently doing, what you cannot do? And just kind of give us a sense of your plans for t
componenttext: So I guess, Rob, with regard to the -- your outlook for the integration of Comcast, can you give a sense of what's your time frame after the deal closes, what you're currently doing, what you cannot do? And just kind of give us a sense of your plans for that. And also related to that, when you think about margins between Time Warner Cable and Comcast, the couple or so hundred point differential, where do you see the biggest opportunities, post-merger, to kind of narrow that gap within Time Warner Cable?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tuna, I'm not sure I can add much to what Comcast has already said on this front. And obviously, the ultimate responsibility for integration, although we're certainly working with Comcast and Charter for that matter on planning for integration today, the
componenttext: Tuna, I'm not sure I can add much to what Comcast has already said on this front. And obviously, the ultimate responsibility for integration, although we're certainly working with Comcast and Charter for that matter on planning for integration today, the responsibility for truly integrating the 2 companies will lie with Comcast and Charter, respectively, so probably best to ask them on exactly what the time frame is. At the outset of the -- at the announcement of the transaction, we jointly focused on an opportunity to create $1.5 billion of cost synergies, and I think Comcast has reiterated its confidence in those numbers since that date. And those opportunities come from elimination of duplicative functions as much -- probably more than anything else. So I'm not sure that there's much for me to add to that. It's really a Comcast question.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
