componenttext: Hello, and welcome to the Time Warner Cable First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I'll turn the call over to Mr. Tom Robey, Senior Vice President of Time Warner Cable, Investor Relations. Thank you, sir, you may begin.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Time Warner Cable's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we issued a press release detailing our 2015 first quarter results.Before we begin, there are several items I need to cover. First, we refer to certain non-GAAP
componenttext:
Welcome to Time Warner Cable's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we issued a press release detailing our 2015 first quarter results.
Before we begin, there are several items I need to cover. 
First, we refer to certain non-GAAP measures. Definitions and schedules setting out reconciliations of these historical non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are included in our earnings release and trending schedules. 
Second, today's conference call includes certain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, which are based on management's current expectations and beliefs and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results may vary materially from those expressed or implied by the statements herein due to various factors which are discussed in detail in our SEC filings. 
Time Warner Cable is under no obligation to, and in fact, expressly disclaims any such obligation, to update or alter its forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
Third, the quarterly growth rates disclosed on this conference call are on a year-over-year basis, unless otherwise noted as being sequential. 
Fourth, today's press release, trending schedules, presentation slides and related reconciliation schedules are available on our website at twc.com/investors.
And finally, following prepared comments by Rob Marcus and Artie Minson, Rob, Artie and our COO, Dinni Jain will be available to answer your questions. 
With that covered, I'll thank you and I'll turn the call over to Rob. Rob?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. While the termination of our merger with Comcast and speculation of our other M&A continue to grab most of the headlines, this morning I'd like to focus on the fundamental strength of our business. In short, I beli
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. While the termination of our merger with Comcast and speculation of our other M&A continue to grab most of the headlines, this morning I'd like to focus on the fundamental strength of our business. In short, I believe we are as well-positioned for the future as any company in our industry. To be blunt, that was not the case when we entered 2014 and I couldn't be more pleased with the strides we've made. We have a world-class team and incredibly strong operating momentum and I am confident that will translate into significant financial growth going forward. 
Over the last 16 months, while most people outside our company were focused more on the merger than on what we were actually doing with the business, we've been quietly executing on the operating plan we shared with you before the Comcast deal was announced. While we were confident that the transaction would be consummated, back in February of last year I gave our operating team very clear instructions, in the unlikely event this deal doesn't close, be ready. 
And by being ready, I meant getting the residential operations in the strongest position possible by putting the right people in the right jobs, investing in our network and customer premises equipment, enhancing our products, improving customer service and making sure our marketing, sales and retention machine was functioning at a really high level. 
By being ready, I also meant making sure we continue to see the huge opportunity we have in Business Services. By expanding our network, adding into our product portfolio, automating and standardizing our process and improving productivity. As I sit here today, I will tell you that our team surpassed my wildest expectations. Despite all the merger-related distractions, they never took their eyes off the ball. Our steadily improving operating results over the last 5 quarters are a reflection of those efforts. And our Q1 performance is the clearest sign yet that we are as operationally strong as we've been in many years. As I said last week, we are strong and getting stronger and I couldn't be prouder to lead this organization. 
By almost any measure, Q1 was our best subscriber quarter ever. We added the most customer relationships ever, the most triple plays ever, the most PSUs ever and the most voice customers ever. And very notably, for the first time since the first quarter of 2009, we added video subs. And we did that while improving the overall quality of our subscriber base. More customers taking higher tiers of service, paying us more for those services and sticking with us longer. That's a potent combination that we are confident sets us up well for accelerated top line growth in the latter part of this year and even more so next year. 
So what's behind the dramatic improvement? The short answer is, we're simply executing better across every facet of our business. I'm sure Dinni, who's really been leading the charge, will give you his perspectives during Q&A. But let me share my view of some of the things that are making a difference. 
First is customer service. Our network operations, care and tech ops teams are playing at the top of their game. During 2014, we made significant investments to improve the reliability of our network. As we've discussed before, our advanced diagnostic tools now allow us to identify those components of our plan that are likely to result in customer impacting issues. We've been using that information to proactively address network problems before they have an impact on our customers. In and of itself, that's obviously good for customers. But it also means we're getting fewer calls to our call centers. Less activity in the call centers allows us to improve service levels, which is the speed in which we answer our calls. And it gives our reps more time to effectively address those problems that do arise. 
We've also invested in better training and tools for our reps so more problems can be held over the phone. In Q1, that resulted in 15% fewer truck rolls for repairs than a year ago and 27% fewer than in the first quarter of 2013. When we do roll a truck, we're giving customers industry-leading 1-hour service windows. And in Q1, we arrived within those windows an impressive 97% of the time. That's an all-time high. And we're continuing to add weekend and nighttime appointments as well. In short, we're serving customers on their schedules rather than ours. 
Not only we made great strides in customer service, but our products are better too. We're completing the rollout of a fivefold increase in VOD capacity this quarter. We've also continued to enhance our TWC TV screening app. In fact, we recently added TWC TV to the Xbox One platform, customers are responding enthusiastically. We set another all-time usage in March with 55% more visits than a year earlier. At the same time, we've continued to expand our WiFi network. And March usage was more than 3x higher than last years. And we continue to add value to our phone products. As of this month, our phone customers can make unlimited calls to India for no additional charge. We already include unlimited call to Mexico and China so TWC phone customers now have unlimited access to around 40% of the world's population. 
We continue to install new more capable equipment in our customers homes, we accelerate the pace in the first quarter, installing almost 2.4 million new modems, set-top boxes and digital adapters. 
And TWC Maxx continues to perform to transform the customer experience from millions of households in the TWC footprint. With Maxx, customers get greater reliability, All Digital video, standard tier speeds of 50 megabits per second and higher tiers of service, which speeds up to 300 megabits per second. New York City, L.A. and Austin are complete, Dallas, San Antonio and Kansas City are underway, and Charlotte, Raleigh and Hawaii are on the docket for later in the year. We also plan to begin the Maxx process in San Diego this year and finish up in early 2016. It's still early days, but Maxx certainly appears to be making a difference. Customer feedback has been great and churn among Maxx customers with new DOCSIS 3.0 modems is dramatically low. 
And with all these customer experience enhancements as a backdrop, our customer acquisition retention machine is firing on all cylinders. The robust $90 triple play offer that we introduced back in October continued to resonate with customers and drove meaningful year-over-year improvements in connect volume. 
Our sales channels performed very well with online growing most significantly. Churn rate and absolute disconnects were also down year-over-year despite the fact that we increased rates and fees in Q1 this year versus Q2 last year, quite an achievement. 
In Business Services, I'm convinced that we have the best team in the industry. We again generated terrific results in Q1 as we executed from our proven playbook. For the 15th quarter in a row, the Business Services revenue grew more than $100 million year-over-year. And with improving margins, Business Services with the contribution is growing even faster than the top line. 
And we continued to invest for the future. At quarter end, we've got 911,000 commercial buildings on-net, which sets us up well for future sales growth. Our Q1 revenue run rate was over $3.1 billion and we're right on track to reach $5 billion in annual revenue by 2018. 
So in summary, I feel great about the overall health and trajectory of our business. We've made significant investments to drive performance and those investments are paying off. We are a far stronger company than we were just 5 short quarters ago. 
As we look towards the balance of 2015, from an operating perspective, we'll keep doing what we've done so well for the last 16 months including continuing to make the necessary investments to set us up operationally and financially for 2016 and beyond. 
As for capital allocation, the fact that we've deleveraged while we waited for deal approval is not lost on us. It's been a busy week but rest assured, we will be working with our board on our go-forward plans with respect to dividends and buybacks. 
Before I pass it over to Artie, and with the Comcast merger now in our rearview mirror, I want to reiterate a couple of things that I said to you back in January of last year on my first earnings call as Time Warner Cable's CEO. I told you that I believe Time Warner Cable had terrific assets, a world-class team and a well architected operating plan. And that I was confident in our ability to drive growth. I also told you that I was totally committed to maximizing shareholder value. Both of those statements are as true today as they were 15 months ago. I firmly believe that everything we've done over the last year plus validates what I said back then. We look forward to your continued support as we move this great company forward. 
Now, let me turn it over to Artie to cover the key takeaways from our first quarter results. Artie?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob. And good morning, everyone. I would like to start by echoing Rob's remarks that we are incredibly appreciative of the efforts of our entire organization over the last 16 months. Under at best, uncertain and at times difficult circumstances ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob. And good morning, everyone. I would like to start by echoing Rob's remarks that we are incredibly appreciative of the efforts of our entire organization over the last 16 months. Under at best, uncertain and at times difficult circumstances our employees performed really well and I would note both admirably and with grace under pressure. We are stronger and better today because of their efforts. 
Before I get into our results today, to help set some overall context, I want to spend a few minutes reviewing what we said we would do 15 months ago when we laid out our 3-year plan. To summarize, our remarks on the January 2014 call, we said that over the next 3 years: First, we would improve the overall residential experience; second, we would continue to aggressively drive Business Services toward our 2018 revenue target of $5 billion; third, we would pursue operating efficiencies and more than offset cost pressure in programming and make investments in tech ops and care in order to improve the customer experience; and fourth, we would meaningfully increase CapEx with our particular focus on plant reliability and making sure our customers have the best CPE available. 
I think our results today demonstrate that we have made great strides in these 4 areas. Our residential operating performance is the best in years. Business Services continues to deliver excellent results. And despite the fact that we've had very significant growth in recent years, we still have tremendous opportunities for growth given our relatively low market share. Our initiatives surround TWC Maxx, plant reliability and CPE replacement are resulting in happier customers and our operations running much smoother. 
And despite the merger-related distractions, we made good strides in cost areas such as phone cost, optimizing our marketing spend, as well as shared functions where expenses were flat year-over-year. I do think there are some remaining opportunities in cost and it is something we will continue to be diligent about. 
Of course, the proof of the success of our operating initiatives is in the metrics. We said back in January 2014 that the operating measures of success would be improved plant and product reliability metrics, reduced call volumes, increased customer satisfaction, lower customer churn and better connect volumes. For those of you keeping score in our recent operating performance, I would give us very high marks across-the-board. 
With that as background, let me turn to the Q1 highlights starting with customer relationships where we performed exceptionally well. On the residential side, we gained 205,000 customer relationships in Q1. And in Business Services, we added 14,000 customer relationships. So on a combined basis, we had our best results ever. 
The Q1 residential CR performance was driven by a 5% increase in connects, coupled by a 2% improvement in disconnects. Much of the connect strength this quarter was driven by online sales. Connect activity was strong in all of our geographic regions, customer relationship net adds were particularly strong in the Pac West of which the Los Angeles Metro area is the largest component. 
PSU performance in Q1 also was outstanding. Residential PSU net adds of 665,000 were 323,000 better than last year's Q1 and 688,000 better than in 2013. The PSU growth was driven by strong triple play net adds. Residential triple play net adds of 298,000 were the best ever. Triples were 39% of customers relationship connects in Q1, similar to the rate in Q4 but twice the selling rate of a year ago. 
On an individual product basis, residential video net adds of 30,000 represent a milestone as it was the first positive video quarter since the first quarter of 2009. Recall that May and June are seasonally tougher. But I will tell you, that we did a positive video net adds in the month of April. The story in terms of video sub quality is also a good one. The real action was at the high-end which generated more than 100% of this quarter's video net adds. 
Broadband volume also was very strong. Residential net adds of 315,000 were the best for a first quarter in 8 years. Again, the quality of the subscriber base continues to increase as our highest speed tiers experience virtually all of the inflow. Our light tier, on the other hand, generated less than 13% of connects, down from a year ago. 
Phone net adds of 320,000 were the strongest ever. This has helped us drive triple play sell in and we also continued to benefit from new product rollouts in phone such as free call into Mexico, China and now, India. 
With that, let's move on to our Q1 financial results. Let me start by saying that despite the fact that adjusted OIBDA had grown 0.8%, I am pleased with our overall financial performance. I'll provide some context around the bigger picture in a few minutes. But first, I'll walk you through a more granular review of the numbers. 
Let me start with total revenue which was $5.8 billion, up 3.5% year-over-year. We grew Residential Services revenue by $94 million or 2.1%, the highest organic year-over-year Residential revenue growth in over 3 years. We implemented certain fee and rate increases in the quarter that benefited ARPU and new connect ARPU was 2.3%. Revenue performance of the video product was notably better in Q1 with video ARPU increasing 2.3% year-over-year. 
In Residential, we talked for some time about returning to a more balanced mixture of volume and rate. This quarter, we've reached that more sustainable balance. In Q1, roughly 50% of the revenue growth was driven by rate and 50% by volume. This will bounce around a little bit based on the timing of rate increases and normal seasonality but the goal is to strike that balance. 
In Business Services, revenue increased $113 million or 16.9% year-over-year in Q1. This is now a big business and we're getting the scale efficiency as we planned for. In the first quarter, Business Services' contribution margin grew by 19.2%, resulting in overall margin expanding 110 basis points year-over-year to 61.3%. 
High-speed data led the same with year-over-year revenue growth of almost 23%. Within that category, dedicated Internet access is experiencing the fastest growth. 
Other operations revenue declined 0.5% in Q1. Media sales revenue was down $17 million from last year. Roughly half of the decline was due to the well-known cyclicality of political advertising. And the rest I think reflects a generally soft TV advertising environment right now, particularly in tune-in where our local ad sales in New York and L.A. were impacted. 
First quarter other revenue increased primarily due to affiliate freeze from our Residential Services segment for SportsNet L.A. These revenues are eliminated in consolidation. As noted, we grew total company adjusted OIBDA 0.8% in Q1 as operating expenses grew 5%. 
Let me make 3 points about what's driving this. 
First, there are certain areas where we're making aggressive investments, notably tech ops and customer care, which together increased $49 million or 8.5%. The entire rationale behind the spending is to serve customers better, enabling us over time to improve ARPU and reduce churn. We are very confident in our ability to continue to drive better financial performance through these investments. 
Second, we've seen expense growth in a couple of categories that, frankly, were higher than we'd like. Company-wide programming and content cost grew $110 million or 8.4% year-over-year in the first quarter and programming cost for residential basic sub grew 12.2%. The programming growth rate was impacted by new network launches like SEC Network and the Dodgers RSN. But even normalizing for those, we would still be north of 10% on a per basic sub basis. In addition, we have significant pension expense, I don't think investors focused much on this because many of our peers don't have the defined benefit plans. But the expense grew $26 million year-over-year in Q1 representing 130 basis points of adjusted OIBDA growth. 
And third, there are some areas where we have been able to exercise tremendous cost discipline. Most notable here are the shared function operating cost associated with broad corporate functions like accounting and finance, IT, legal and HR where we had held expenses flat year-over-year at $727 million. I will tell you that we're vigilant on shared cost. 
Another way of looking at OIBDA growth in Q1, if you exclude the decline in advertising revenue and the increase in pension expense, our adjusted OIBDA growth would have been 3%. Now looking at the bigger picture, we're just about where we expected to be. As we contemplated in our 3-year plan, 2015 is a transitional year, focused more on sub growth now which we expect will drive significant financial growth in 2016. It is the case that our 2015 revenue and adjusted OIBDA expectations are below a very stale consensus. And I recognize that by not giving 2015 guidance on our last earnings call, we didn't help bridge that gap. 
So given some of the headwinds I discussed in pension, Dodgers and ad sales, as well as the operating investments we're making, let me tell you that we expect 2015 to be flattish from an adjusted OIBDA growth standpoint. 
Looking forward, we are confident that 2016 will be very strong from a financial standpoint with adjusted OIBDA of around $9 billion. Think of the business like a flywheel, it takes a lot of energy to get the flywheel going. But once it is going, it's momentum will keep it spinning for a long time. Similarly, in our business, you have too spend to get the subscriber machine running. But once it's running like our flywheel is now, you're in a great position to deliver strong, sustainable financial growth. 
Moving down the income statement. First quarter adjusted diluted EPS was $1.65, down $0.13 from a year ago. One of the biggest drivers of lower EPS in Q1 was depreciation expense which again is a clear reflection of the massive investments we're making to improve the operations and future prospects of this company. And I would remind you that with the suspension of our share repurchase program when we announced the Comcast transaction, shares outstanding were actually up 4 million year-over-year. This compares to the prior year 2 years when shares outstanding were coming down at least 14 million shares a year. 
Free cash flow was $407 million in the first quarter, down $222 million year-over-year. Primarily due to the $300 million year-over-year increase in capital investments. Remember also that while bonus depreciation was extended at the end of 2014, it happened so late in the year that we had treated all of our 2014 federal tax payments as if it wouldn't be extended. And since we don't make a payment in Q1, we'll get a Q2 benefit of approximately $120 million due to the overpayment of federal taxes last year. 
CapEx of $1.1 billion in the first quarter was the highest ever in a first quarter, reflecting improvements to the plan, our aggressive investments in CPE as we continue to deploy new set-tops, digital adapters and modems in Maxx markets and our accelerated replacement of older, less reliable set-tops across the footprint. 
We also continued to invest in the future growth of Business Services. We connected nearly 12,000 commercial buildings to our network in Q1 and increased our serviceable revenue opportunity to approximately $18 billion. As indicated, we were spending aggressively on CapEx ahead of the anticipated merger closing. Coupling that with our initiatives to the rest of 2015 will result in full year CapEx being a little higher than last year. 
Finally, we are also working through our go-forward capital allocation plans with the board, as Rob noted. We obviously delevered over the last 14 months and are currently levered at approximately 2.9x with the usual adjustments. We realized that smart capital allocation including buybacks and dividend increases has been a big part of the Time Warner Cable story and we expect it to be in the future along with the opportunity for significant go-forward value creation from ongoing improvements in operations. 
With that, let me turn it back over to Tom for the Q&A portion of the call.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: Craig, it's Rob, I'll take it. You know that we're not really going to respond to questions about any M&A except to say that one, as we've made abundantly clear this morning, we feel great about the operating health of our business right now. And two, we're going to be guided by the same principles that guided us here too which is doing much in the best interest of our shareholders. Period.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Craig, this is Dinni. It's always tempting to look at it is a completely zero-sum gain. If we are growing, that absolutely means that somebody is doing something bad or not executing as well as they want to. I think the reality is, there are a lot of jump
componenttext: Craig, this is Dinni. It's always tempting to look at it is a completely zero-sum gain. If we are growing, that absolutely means that somebody is doing something bad or not executing as well as they want to. I think the reality is, there are a lot of jump balls as we call them, every time a customer moves, every time a customer's looking to change, and we are winning a lot more on those jump balls than we were winning last year or the year before. And I think that's a because we are so focused, we're so focused on a lot of small things from an execution standpoint. And I think we are slowly winning those things. So I don't think that there is a great answer there for you. We have a triple play offer, that's not dissimilar from a lot of the others in the industry. We're not in particularly really aggressive in our offers or in our promotions. But what we are doing is executing very well on both sales and marketing, but particularly in care and tech ops.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd throw in, in addition to what Dinni just said, our performance is improving against all competitors. And in fact, when you look at our performing in markets where we compete with FiOS and U-verse, connects are up and disconnects are dow
componenttext: The only thing I'd throw in, in addition to what Dinni just said, our performance is improving against all competitors. And in fact, when you look at our performing in markets where we compete with FiOS and U-verse, connects are up and disconnects are down and that really reflects the strength we are seeing against all players.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: Next question is Jessica Cohen of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: Also 2 questions if it's okay. First on your calendar '16 guidance. It's a bit lower than what you had said in the past, what changed?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jessica, it's Artie. There's a couple of things I would point out. One is obviously, pension, we talked about $26 million year-over-year in Q1 so we annualize that, that is $100 million right there. The second is obviously, we do not have a Dodgers deal a
componenttext: Jessica, it's Artie. There's a couple of things I would point out. One is obviously, pension, we talked about $26 million year-over-year in Q1 so we annualize that, that is $100 million right there. The second is obviously, we do not have a Dodgers deal at this point, so that certainly has an impact. And programming cost have also been higher than we had anticipated. Obviously, 12.2% per basic sub growth was more than we had anticipated than when we did the plan.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jessica was your question '15 or '16?
componenttext: Jessica was your question '15 or '16?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It was already '16 and my answer is really apply into '15. I think at '16, you also have -- add sales is also -- we would be presumably off of a lower base going into next year as well. So that also had an impact.
componenttext: It was already '16 and my answer is really apply into '15. I think at '16, you also have -- add sales is also -- we would be presumably off of a lower base going into next year as well. So that also had an impact.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just say, Jessica, to the overall comment, relative to the 3-year plan we articulated prior to the announcement of the Comcast deal, we feel very good about how we are tracking. Any plan, you have puts and takes some things you're head on, some th
componenttext: I would just say, Jessica, to the overall comment, relative to the 3-year plan we articulated prior to the announcement of the Comcast deal, we feel very good about how we are tracking. Any plan, you have puts and takes some things you're head on, some things you are a little bit behind on. With respect to subscriber metrics, we are tracking extremely. We're ahead of where we thought we'd be. With respect to underlying operating metrics, how we're doing in terms of improving the customer experience, we're ahead. Admittedly, that's requiring some additional investment and as a result, we are tracking a little bit behind on our OIBDA. But overall I feel like we're tracking very well against the plan.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And my second question actually relates to the tremendous grow that you had, the improvement in video subs. It's really encouraging how much to be improved on the last few quarters. What is your longer-term view of kind of pay TV penetration and the bundl
componenttext: And my second question actually relates to the tremendous grow that you had, the improvement in video subs. It's really encouraging how much to be improved on the last few quarters. What is your longer-term view of kind of pay TV penetration and the bundle overall? Could you give us how do you see this playing out, we'll we have a full bundle, which seems to be a better value proposition. Or do think consumers really want skinny packages? Will they move to OTC, you guys think about it?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there's a lot of play left in the plan that we're executing right now. I think there's a lot of play left with triple play. Just a little a while ago, people were acting like the phone product was completely dead and the ability for us to go out a
componenttext: I think there's a lot of play left in the plan that we're executing right now. I think there's a lot of play left with triple play. Just a little a while ago, people were acting like the phone product was completely dead and the ability for us to go out and aggressively sell phone as part of a triple play was very limited. And I think we've shown that that's not actually the case. While there's a lot of attraction in the press about skinny packages I think a lot of the times customers that want to get bogged down in a lot of choices to make on those kinds of things. I mean, there's a lot of value in our triple play packaging right now. And it's a simpler sale. Anything that there's a lot of play in that. And I think that in terms of skinny packages, we don't want to be pioneers on that. I mean, there's a lot of talk and a lot of work going on out there from other guys and if any of their things will work, we'll just be followers on that stuff. Because there are some segments of our customer base where that is going to have appeal.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question on Dan Finberg of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question on Dan Finberg of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Artie, just quickly. Is 3.24 leverage still the target of North Star that we should be thinking about? And just to clarify are you assuming the Dodgers are carried in '16 -- in the '16 guidance or not? And then my real question maybe for Rob or Dinni, the
componenttext: Artie, just quickly. Is 3.24 leverage still the target of North Star that we should be thinking about? And just to clarify are you assuming the Dodgers are carried in '16 -- in the '16 guidance or not? And then my real question maybe for Rob or Dinni, the customer metrics are clearly strong. I think you guys have had your new kind of pricing and packaging out for about a year. But the ARPU growth -- and you had some price increases in Q1, the revenue growth per customer relationship is about 1%. And I'm wondering, given you talked about high-quality subs, coming in on both video and data and we should be lapping some early promos why isn't that number higher now? And do you expect that to accelerate this year or is that really more going to take place next year based on your current plan?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Artie. Let me -- with respect to the Dodgers, I'm not going to get into sort of any of the specifics underlying assumptions in the plan. We continue to think the Dodgers product is a great product and I will leave it at that. In the 3.24, as I i
componenttext: Dan, it's Artie. Let me -- with respect to the Dodgers, I'm not going to get into sort of any of the specifics underlying assumptions in the plan. We continue to think the Dodgers product is a great product and I will leave it at that. In the 3.24, as I indicated in my proactive remarks, we will be engaging with the board on a sort of review of our overall capital allocation philosophy. So I frankly don't want to get ahead of those conversations either. One, before I turn it over to Rob and Dinni on the ARPU per CR, one thing I would just sort of point out is, we are, which is a good thing, increasing the denominator on customer relationships. We are adding new customers and they tend to come in at a lower ARPU than the rest of the base. The good news is they're coming in, the new customers, at a higher rate than they had in the past. But still, they come in less of the overall base. But we make that trade off all day long.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think Artie hit it on the head. Some of it is just math. The better you do in terms of volume, almost definitionally given that we live in a world where customers come in on promotional pricing, that means that ARPU comes down and that's why I always co
componenttext: I think Artie hit it on the head. Some of it is just math. The better you do in terms of volume, almost definitionally given that we live in a world where customers come in on promotional pricing, that means that ARPU comes down and that's why I always counsel against putting too much stock in ARPU on its own. Really what you want to focus on is where overall revenue is going and that's why we're so pleased with the organic revenue growth in residential, which is the best it's been in over 2 years -- 3 years, excuse me. So look, I think we feel very good about the quality of the subs. Customers are coming in at higher tiers of service. In video, we added 30,000 video customers. In fact, we added close to 150,000 to our Preferred tier of service. Similarly, HSD customers are coming in at higher tiers of service, higher-speed tiers. And interestingly enough, we are less reliant for growth than we had been in the past on our light tiers of HSD service. So I think all this bodes well for ARPU improvements down the road and I'm not troubled at all by what seems like lower ARPU growth than we've had in the past.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is John Hodulik with UBS.
componenttext: Next question is John Hodulik with UBS.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions around the CapEx guidance. You guys did about 20% of sales this quarter, up pretty meaningfully versus on a year ago number. Is that 20% a good number? I know it's a ways out. But does this CapEx fall in '16 I mean, shifting sor
componenttext: Just a couple of questions around the CapEx guidance. You guys did about 20% of sales this quarter, up pretty meaningfully versus on a year ago number. Is that 20% a good number? I know it's a ways out. But does this CapEx fall in '16 I mean, shifting sort of, the top? How do you expect that percentage of sales turn sort of flow through?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we didn't give 2016 capital guidance today. And I'm not in the proactive remarks and I'm not going to give any additional color today. What I will tell you is we continue to be really pleased with the returns we're seeing on our CapEx spend. It
componenttext: Obviously, we didn't give 2016 capital guidance today. And I'm not in the proactive remarks and I'm not going to give any additional color today. What I will tell you is we continue to be really pleased with the returns we're seeing on our CapEx spend. It has -- I think the proof is obviously, in our operating performance. Our customer metrics where we sat last year there were things where we really wanted to accomplish when we made the investments, which was improve our product reliability, improve our network reliability, make sure our customers had the best equipment in their homes for new customers go into existing customers home and take out equipment that we thought was not optimizing the experience. And I think the proof is in the subscribers results today. So to the extent that we continue to see those results, which we expect to, I think that obviously requires capital but there's a great return of that capital. Obviously, also we continue to invest in Business Services. The business is at a $3.1 billion run rate, we add 12,000 buildings to the network this quarter and that's another place you're going to continue to see investments but although that has very, very good returns on it.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Phil Cusick of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next question is Phil Cusick of JPMorgan.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Same topic from a different direction. As I think about the all digital pacing, where do think you can be in terms of markets or subscriber or footprint by the end of '15 and when does the all digital transition sort of get done? And then the other side o
componenttext: Same topic from a different direction. As I think about the all digital pacing, where do think you can be in terms of markets or subscriber or footprint by the end of '15 and when does the all digital transition sort of get done? And then the other side of it is on the set-top box, your high-end box I would say is much better than you've had historically, but probably not up to the level of an X1 and some of the competitors, how do think about the durability of that box in the marketplace long-term and do you think about doing something else?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phil, we've laid out the schedule for rolling out TWC Maxx, which really includes the all digital conversion. I think that takes us to somewhere between 40% and 50% of the footprint by the end of the year in terms of homes passed. And the exact pace at wh
componenttext: Phil, we've laid out the schedule for rolling out TWC Maxx, which really includes the all digital conversion. I think that takes us to somewhere between 40% and 50% of the footprint by the end of the year in terms of homes passed. And the exact pace at which we continued that process in '16 and '17, I think in part depends on the experience we have in '15 we're feeling better about our ability to roll out All Digital this year than we did last year, which was really the first year of the program. And we'll evaluate as we go into '16 how quickly we think we can ramp the next batch of systems, so that's the pacing. In terms of the set-top box question, I think your question really goes to the guide or the user interface as opposed of the box. Is that correct?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right.
componenttext: Yes, that's right.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So look, right now we have, I believe, 8 million set-top boxes. So a real mass deployment when I think of it is a very robust cloud-based guide. And I think that concept of having a guide in front of that many -- that greater proportion of our total
componenttext: Okay. So look, right now we have, I believe, 8 million set-top boxes. So a real mass deployment when I think of it is a very robust cloud-based guide. And I think that concept of having a guide in front of that many -- that greater proportion of our total subscriber base, might be ahead than the rest of the package industry. The current version of that guide has a great, rich graphical user interface, and we've seen the impact of that already in that usage of VOD amongst customers who have that guide is a lot higher than on the prior boxes. So I feel very good about where we are in terms of the guide. We do have a next generation cloud-based guide, which is following this one, which is in some paying customers homes right now and will be more broadly deployed in the back half of this year. But not only makes what we've got even better. I feel very good about the current guide offering.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Richard Greenfield of BTIG.
componenttext: Next question is Richard Greenfield of BTIG.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. As video ARPU improved from last year-over-year, Q1 last year, until Q1 '15 while you're high-speed ARPU growth went from up 9 a year ago to only up 3, why is data ARPU growth slowing while video ARPU growth is improving. I assume t
componenttext: A couple of questions. As video ARPU improved from last year-over-year, Q1 last year, until Q1 '15 while you're high-speed ARPU growth went from up 9 a year ago to only up 3, why is data ARPU growth slowing while video ARPU growth is improving. I assume there's discounting in there as well as kind of year-over-year rate increased timing. I mean, could give us a bit more clarity on how those [indiscernible] are performance?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rich, it's Artie. What you may recall is if you go back over a year ago, we were doing what I would call product rate increases. So you may in one point in a year get a video rate increase and you may another point of the year get an HSD increase. You may
componenttext: Rich, it's Artie. What you may recall is if you go back over a year ago, we were doing what I would call product rate increases. So you may in one point in a year get a video rate increase and you may another point of the year get an HSD increase. You may recall in the comparison you had, that we increased our HSD modem fee and that drove HSD ARPU in that year. This year when we went out we went to what we call the unified rate increase, which was one increase to a customer per year regardless of the number of products and that had more of an allocation across the different product lines of that increase. So as we've said in the past, we tend to not sort of focus too much on the individual product's ARPUs but that is -- that difference in approach to how we do rate increases is impacting the year-over-year product ARPU comparisons.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just a question for Rob, because I think this is the elephant in the room in terms of your stock price. Like how do you think about the value of your stock given performance of the company today versus a year ago. Obviously, stock is up a lot fro
componenttext: And then just a question for Rob, because I think this is the elephant in the room in terms of your stock price. Like how do you think about the value of your stock given performance of the company today versus a year ago. Obviously, stock is up a lot from when you had a whole bunch of approaches over a year ago. How do you think about the value of where your stock is currently trading? And how investments [indiscernible] the company in the current level?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rich, connection is lousy, I heard only a part of it. But I think I got the gist. We are not going to comment except to say that everything we said today supports the notion that we feel great about the spot we're in. We think that our strength yields ter
componenttext: Rich, connection is lousy, I heard only a part of it. But I think I got the gist. We are not going to comment except to say that everything we said today supports the notion that we feel great about the spot we're in. We think that our strength yields terrific confidence for the future and we're pleased with the overall health of the business. Period. End of story.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Jason with Citi.
componenttext: Next question is Jason with Citi.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question maybe for Mr. Marcus. Strange one about positive net adds on video but I know investors care about it given some of the bigger changes maybe going on in the industry. If a customer ends up terminating their video subscription with yo
componenttext: Just a quick question maybe for Mr. Marcus. Strange one about positive net adds on video but I know investors care about it given some of the bigger changes maybe going on in the industry. If a customer ends up terminating their video subscription with you and you have, whatever it is, $35 gross profit shortfall, how do you internally think about bridging the gap to claw back to breakeven? In other words, is it taking standalone data hires, consumption data, are there other costs there where video is profitable, as it may appear just how do you think about that?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jason, I've been asked that question numerous times in the past and I think it kind of departs from the reality of the marketplace. At the end of the day, we've got to figure out how to have competitive products that are really compelling to customers. So
componenttext: Jason, I've been asked that question numerous times in the past and I think it kind of departs from the reality of the marketplace. At the end of the day, we've got to figure out how to have competitive products that are really compelling to customers. So it's not so simple as taking money from 1 bucket and sticking it in another bucket. We're very focused on delivering compelling products to customers at a price that delivers real value. And on that, we think the rest is going to work itself out. But we can't think in terms of taking gross margin dollars that are lost because we lose a video customer and somehow embedding those into HSD and not seeing an impact on HSD. So I think we're going to -- not really think about the world quite that way.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Amy Yong from Macquarie.
componenttext: Next question is Amy Yong from Macquarie.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question is actually on AT&T and DIRECTV I guess, with the merger closing around May, June. Do you anticipate any bigger changes on the promotional side or competitive landscape? And then, just really quickly, Artie, how do you think about cash taxes f
componenttext: My question is actually on AT&T and DIRECTV I guess, with the merger closing around May, June. Do you anticipate any bigger changes on the promotional side or competitive landscape? And then, just really quickly, Artie, how do you think about cash taxes for this year?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: On DIRECTV and AT&T, obviously, that deal has not yet closed. And at this point, no, we don't anticipate any change really in the promotional pricing. Arguably, the deal like that where 2 companies that actually do compete with one another in the marketpl
componenttext: On DIRECTV and AT&T, obviously, that deal has not yet closed. And at this point, no, we don't anticipate any change really in the promotional pricing. Arguably, the deal like that where 2 companies that actually do compete with one another in the marketplace, if it were to close would reduce the number of competitors in the marketplace. And as a general matter, that's good for the other participants in the marketplace. So I'm not terribly worried about it.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Amy, on cash taxes, at this point, our outlook is about $475 million for the year. There was an extension of bonus depreciation that may reduce cash taxes by another $100 million, if you recall that last year it happened so late in the year that frank
componenttext: And Amy, on cash taxes, at this point, our outlook is about $475 million for the year. There was an extension of bonus depreciation that may reduce cash taxes by another $100 million, if you recall that last year it happened so late in the year that frankly, we had already made our estimated tax payments. So with no extension, you're sort of looking in the $475 million range.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Tom Eagan with Telsey Advisors.
componenttext: Next question is Tom Eagan with Telsey Advisors.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rob, I think with the last earnings call, you mentioned that the CBC WiFi offer was interesting but you felt the need for some kind of backup. Any comments on WiFi?
componenttext: Rob, I think with the last earnings call, you mentioned that the CBC WiFi offer was interesting but you felt the need for some kind of backup. Any comments on WiFi?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I have much to answer to what I said last quarter. We continue to be big fans of WiFi. Our high-speed data customers now I think have access to something like 400,000 WiFi Hotspots across the country when you include both the WiFi Hotspots th
componenttext: I'm not sure I have much to answer to what I said last quarter. We continue to be big fans of WiFi. Our high-speed data customers now I think have access to something like 400,000 WiFi Hotspots across the country when you include both the WiFi Hotspots that we've deployed and the WiFi Hotspots of our various cable partners. I think that's a great value add. We saw increased usage amongst our high-speed data customers of WiFi this quarter. So we'll continue to invest to broaden that network because we think it makes our high-speed data product that much more attractive. Whether or not there's a play which is more of a cellular replacement strategy, which may include voice, I think, that remains to be seen. I said that I thought the free wheel offering from Cablevision was intriguing but I'm inclined to watch and see how that evolves and then we'll see how best to develop our own strategy on that front.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Marci Ryvicker with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Next question is Marci Ryvicker with Wells Fargo.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: In your prepared remarks you talked about the timing of rate increases this year versus last year. Can you say anything about the magnitude? And then secondly, given all of the uncertainty obviously going around the deal, how are you positioned from a per
componenttext: In your prepared remarks you talked about the timing of rate increases this year versus last year. Can you say anything about the magnitude? And then secondly, given all of the uncertainty obviously going around the deal, how are you positioned from a personnel perspective? Is there going to be some sort of hiring outreach?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the rate increases, Marci, some of them hit Q1 and we'll basically get a full quarter impact on Q2. You will recall that last year as I said, it's almost a seachange of how we did rate increases. Whereas last year, we had more rate increases in differe
componenttext: On the rate increases, Marci, some of them hit Q1 and we'll basically get a full quarter impact on Q2. You will recall that last year as I said, it's almost a seachange of how we did rate increases. Whereas last year, we had more rate increases in different quarters particularly around HSD and modem fees. So really a different approach. What I would tell you is, overall this year, our rate increases went to more customers but the average customer got a meaningfully lower rate increase. So we talked a lot about the goal of getting back to a balanced uprate and volume. And obviously one of the ways we did that is to not be as dependent on higher rate increases. So we went broader with them but not as much on individual builds.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Marci, as far as the team goes, one of the things that I am proud best has impressed me the most over the course of the last year in change is just how fabulously the team has hung together and performed in the face of what were, at times, challenging cir
componenttext: Marci, as far as the team goes, one of the things that I am proud best has impressed me the most over the course of the last year in change is just how fabulously the team has hung together and performed in the face of what were, at times, challenging circumstances. Bottom line is, this team could hang together through what we just went through. We're about as well-positioned for the future as one could imagine. So I feel very good about where we sit in terms of the team.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Mike MacCormack of Jefferies.
componenttext: Next question is Mike MacCormack of Jefferies.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Artie, maybe just quick comment on the programming expense trend maybe on a per sub basis and what you're contemplating on the guide. And then I guess, one for Rob, thinking about I guess, the future of TV watching, but the demo is there a movement at set
componenttext: Artie, maybe just quick comment on the programming expense trend maybe on a per sub basis and what you're contemplating on the guide. And then I guess, one for Rob, thinking about I guess, the future of TV watching, but the demo is there a movement at set-top or CP like model meeting sort of demand for maybe the current product but only on an apps basis?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the programming increase, we obviously didn't get into any specifics in the full year guide. What I would tell you though is a lot of the dynamics we saw in Q1 do continue through the rest of the year, there are some lapping of products that were launc
componenttext: On the programming increase, we obviously didn't get into any specifics in the full year guide. What I would tell you though is a lot of the dynamics we saw in Q1 do continue through the rest of the year, there are some lapping of products that were launched later in 2014. But we, frankly -- I think, you're not going to see that much of a change this year.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, in terms of the concept of a set-top box less video product, first before I get to it, let me just say, that there tends to be, in my opinion, an excessive interest in millennials maybe at the expense of the broader customer base. And I would tell y
componenttext: Mike, in terms of the concept of a set-top box less video product, first before I get to it, let me just say, that there tends to be, in my opinion, an excessive interest in millennials maybe at the expense of the broader customer base. And I would tell you that, for most of our customers, the vast majority of our customers, the way we currently deliver the video product is pretty darn attractive. That said, sure, there's a group of customers who might very well like to access video via other means and that's one thing we've been incredibly aggressive on over the last several years, is making the video product available on multiple platforms whether it's iOS platforms, iPads and iPhones, Android-based platforms. Most recently we launched the Xbox. So it is definitely the case that over time I could see a world where more and more customers consume our offering without needing to lease a set-top box from us. But that doesn't we're going to abandon the largest portion of our customers who actually do like the current model.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It seems like mode to new truck sort of, installed in a cable modem in savings on that said, in the cost would be an interesting model going forward.
componenttext: It seems like mode to new truck sort of, installed in a cable modem in savings on that said, in the cost would be an interesting model going forward.

componenttext: You're talking about maybe nearly 10% of EBITDA growth in 2016, can you sort of give any sort of breakdown on how much of that is really going to be driven by step ups and promotional pricing versus some of your investments in customer care and tech ops sort of, normalizing so that we can get a better sense and then I have a follow-up.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: DJ, this is Artie. I'll just point out a couple of things to your point to tech ops and customer care, we basically, have had that stairstep increase in investment this year. And so that to your point begins to normalize out. As you think about programmin
componenttext: DJ, this is Artie. I'll just point out a couple of things to your point to tech ops and customer care, we basically, have had that stairstep increase in investment this year. And so that to your point begins to normalize out. As you think about programming, I would think we don't have any new launches on the horizon right now. We also though I think the really key thing is, and I talk a little bit sort of the flywheel of the business, when you start adding subscribers and have that momentum and have a full year of subscriber add win at your back, this year we're still dealing with losing subscribers and losing individual products. Last year it's impacting this year's results. That is sort of the biggest driver of the overall increase. You saw the acceleration in residential growth but that should, that growth rate should continue to accelerate next year and you continue to see strong growth in Business Services and on the ad sales front it's obviously, a political year so that is -- that provides some benefit as well.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: On [indiscernible] broadly obviously, you guys investing on the network and increasing broadband speeds, can you sort of talk about any changes on how you sort of think about raising high-speed data pricing longer-term or the prospect of introducing continuing pricing given on what you know now?

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this point in time, no changes to our overall philosophy. But obviously we're going to be watching closely how things unfold on the Title II front. We've said in the past about our normal business practices comply entirely with the notion of the open I
componenttext:
At this point in time, no changes to our overall philosophy. But obviously we're going to be watching closely how things unfold on the Title II front. We've said in the past about our normal business practices comply entirely with the notion of the open Internet, no blocking, no discrimination, no [indiscernible] and transparency are fundamental parts of the way we do business. So to the extent that that's the full scope of what gets implemented under Title II, I think you won't see a change in the way we do business. To the extent that something more comes from this, as we would describe, excessively rugged authority than we have to revisit the way we're approaching investment and pricing.
I think that's all the time we have for this morning. For those of you planning ahead our Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call will be held on Thursday, July 30, 2015, at 8:30 a.m Eastern Time. Thanks for joining us.

headline: Time Warner Cable Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
